document.docTitle: Pedetontinus maijiensis Zhang & Zhou 2011, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Descriptions of one new genus and six new species of Machilidae (Insecta: Archaeognatha) from China: morphological and molecular data

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Descriptions of one new genus and six new species of Machilidae (Insecta: Archaeognatha) from China: morphological and molecular data

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype .
NNUSB0228 , an adult male; China : Mt Maiji , Tianshui City , Gansu Province , on the uppermost layer of the forest floor consisting chiefly of fallen leaves and other decaying organic matter and on the sandstone covered with moss,
34 ◦ 3 ′ N
,
106 ◦ 0 ′ E
, at an elevation of
1000–1020 m
,
4 August 2006
, coll. J.Y. Zhang.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratypes .
NNUSB0228–0233 , six adult males
;
NNUSB0234–0242 , nine adult females; same data as for holotype
.

Body length 7.0– 8.5 mm ; antennae: 6.8–7.5 mm ; terminal filament: 9.0– 9.5 mm ; cerci: 3.1–4.5 mm . Body brownish grey, covered densely with scales and with pigments. Terga mostly covered with brown scales. No spots present on terga. Epidermic pigment on head capsule, labium, mandibles, maxillae, maxillary palp and legs.

Compound eyes large and brownish, with a huge yellowish patch on inner corner (in alcohol), contact line/length: 0.52; length/width: 0.85–0.86. Paired ocelli shoeshaped, enlarged in submedian area, brownish (in alcohol) with white edge; width of ocellus slightly narrower than that of compound eye (width of ocellus about 0.72–0.75 of that of compound eye).

Mandibles quite robust, provided with four typical apical teeth. Maxillary palp ( Figure 6D ) provided with numerous setae of moderate size. Setae in articles IV– VII denser than those in articles I– III . Articles II – VII scaled densely. Articles IV– VII provided with numerous short setae. External apophysis of article I cone-shaped and slightly curved backwards with setae sparsely on ventral surface. Article II without setae curved inwards, not extending beyond the third article. Article III with dense short setae on ventral surface and few setae on internal distal end, article VII cone-shaped. Dorsal surface of the articles V – VII with hyaline spines as follows: V : 4–6; VI : 10–12; VII : 12–14. Ratio of length article VII / VI : 0.66; article IV/ V : 0.67–0.70.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 6.
Pedetontinus maijiensis
sp. nov. Male (A–J): (A) head, frontal view, (B) the distal chains of flagellum, (C) labium, (D) maxillary palp, (E) fore leg, (F) mid leg, (G) hind leg, (H) urosternite V, (I) urosternite VII, (J) urosternite IX with paramere and penis. Female (K–Y): (K) head, frontal view, (L) the distal chains of flagellum, (M) labium, (N) maxillary palp, (O) fore leg, (P) mid leg, (Q) hind leg, (R) urosternite V, (S) urosternite VII, (T) urosternite VIII with anterior gonapophysis, (U, V) part of gonapophysis VIII, ventral view, (W) urosternite IX with posterior gonapophyses, (X, Y) part of gonapophysis IX, ventral view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Labial palp as in Figure 6C , article I not scaled, articles II , III sparsely scaled and with dense setae; article III almost club like, with sensorial cones on apical part.

Legs ( Figures 6E–G ) and coxal stylets scaled. Mid and hind legs with coxal stylets. Femur of fore leg not swollen, ratio of length to width: 2.0. Spines present on femur, light-coloured. Length of tibia I: 0.50–0.52 mm ; tibia II : 0.46–048 mm; tibia III : 0.64– 0.67 mm . Fore legs stronger than others, tibia of hind legs elongated. Spines in legs as follows: tibia I: 0–1; tibia II : 1–2; tibia III : 3; number of 1–3 segments of tarsus I: 4–6, 8–10, 8–10; tarsus II : 4–6, 8–10, 8–10; tarsus III : 4–6, 8–10, 8–10.

Urosternites not pigmented. Abdominal stylets not especially elongated except IXth segment. Abdominal segments I– VII with a pair of eversible vesicles. Sternum V with nearly right posterior angle (87–89 ◦ ); length/basal width of sternum V ( Figure 6H ): 0.66–0.67. Urosternite VII ( Figure 6I ) without swollen on its inner posterior part.

A penis and a pair of parameres ( Figure 6J ) with 1+4 divisions (or 5 divisions) extending backward to two-thirds of length of the urosternite IX. Penis as long as paramere, ratio of the length of base/tip: 3.0–3.2, opening of penis small and apical. Male genitalia completely covered by the IXth urosternite. Apical spine of abdominal stylets strong, medium-sized. IXth coxite provided with 12–13 spines near apex. Length ratios of stylet (excluding apical spine) to coxite, V : 0.54; VIII : 0.63; IX: 0.64; length ratios of apical spine to stylet, V : 0.37–0.40; VIII : 0.49–0.50; IX: 0.35–0.37.
Terminal filament and cerci without piliform scales, with numerous scales.
Body length 8.0–9.0 mm; antennae: 5.4–6.0 mm; terminal filament: 7.5–8.5 mm ; cerci: 3.5–4.0 mm. Scale pattern and epidermic pigment as in male.

Maxillary palp ( Figure 6N ) as in male. Articles II – VII densely scaled. Article I only scaled on ventral surface, dense setae on articles IV– VII , and article VII coneshaped. Dorsal surface of the articles V – VII with hyaline spines as follows: V : 4–6; VI : 14–16; VII : 14–16. Ratio of length of article VII / VI : 0.77; article IV/ V : 0.66–0.68.

Legs ( Figure 6O–Q ) as in male. Femur of fore leg not swollen, ratio of length to width: 1.80. Spines present on femur, light-coloured. Length of tibia I: 0.48–0.50 mm ; tibia II : 0.49–0.50 mm ; tibia III : 0.69–0.70 mm . Fore leg stronger than others, tibia of hind leg obviously elongated. Spines in legs as follows: tibia I: 1–2; tibia II : 1–2; tibia III : 3; number of 1–3 segments of tarsus I: 4–6, 10–14, 10–12; tarsus II : 4–6, 10–14, 10–12; tarsus III : 4–6, 10–14, 10–12.
Abdominal segments as in male. Length/basal width of sternum V ( Figure 6R ): 0.66–0.67. Medial part of urosternite VII ( Figure 6S ) projected and swollen, exceeding posterior margin.

Ovipositor of the tertiary type and slightly exceeding beyond the stylet of urosternite IX. Gonapophysis VIII ( Figure 6T–V )
with 50–52 divisions, sensilla present except 2–3 basal divisions. Gonapophysis IX ( Figure 6W–Y ) with 50 divisions, the basal 20– 22 divisions with some short setae. IXth coxite provided with eight or nine spines near apex. Length ratios of stylet (excluding apical spine) to coxite, V
: 0.50–0.52; VIII : 0.60–0.62; IX: 0.60–0.62; length ratios of apical spine to stylet, V : 0.48–0.50; VIII : 0.42–0.44; IX: 0.25–0.28.
Terminal filaments and cerci similar to those of male.
The specific name refers to the type locality.
